title: How to write task 1 informal letter band 9 for the general IELTS - Quora

response.answer_text: While there’s no infallible blueprint per se to a 9, there are conventions that can ensure a high band performance: Here I enlist eight vital ingredients that make for a creditable task one casual/informal letter. Ensure that the letter is addressed Dear + first name [ Dear Susan ]the letter begins with a a friendly opening phrase [How are you? I was chuffed to hear from you.]you make use of contractions [ I’ve / he’s / she’s / it’d / they’d / could’ve/ can’t, etc.]phrasal verbs are used to invoke and accentuate the casual register (tone) [ Examples: catch up, check out, get together, put up, drop by, etc.] Native users of the language tend to use these (far) more than non-native users.there is use of idiomatic language and idioms [examples: on the ball, in the same boat, a lot on one’s plate, learn the ropes, etc.]the exclamation mark (!) is used (helps express excitement, which is a quintessentially causal emotion) [Can’t wait for our road trip!]the letter ends with a friendly closing phrase [Have a great trip! Hope to catch up with you soon!]ends with a casual sign-off that features the first name of the writer [Lots of love , (name <in the next line>)]there is the use of more casual, easygoing vocabulary and colloquial, everyday expressions in place of heavy, academic/bookish terms.So there you have it! The idea is to maintain a highly conversational tone since you are writing to someone who is very close to you, and you share a warm and cordial relationship with them. The key here is to maintain an informal register (tone) throughout, ensuring that you do not make lapses into formal tones as you write. Being tone-appropriate is what distinguishes a good writer from a not-so-good one. Now how about if we see all these principles above in execution? Observe through the following model answer that I have authored to illustrate good practices for an informal/causal letter:  Dear Carrie, Hope you’re doing splendidly! I suppose you are, too, what with the camping holiday you’re mulling over for the summer. Oh, going through your mail, I was positively chuffed to learn about that particular bit! You couldn’t have thought of a better way to ginger up the summer! You’re going to love it, getting the city out of your lungs, taking inthe pristine mountain air, getting out the camping grill, cooking out in the open, treating your taste buds as your eyes feast upon the raw beauty that surrounds…it’s the best! So as I understand, you’re headed to the Himalayan lake of Chandratal. Capital choice! I guess my rant about the place’s magical vibe finally got to you! Having been there, I thought I’d clue you in about some things you may want to look out for. The road up there is treacherous, and things tend to get a bit dicey. You want to make sure you’ve got a good pair of hands commanding the wheel. Speaking of which, you might want to consider being on board an SUV to stay on top of things, quite literally too! Also, things tend to get rather chilly post sundown; you may want to pack thick sleeping bags that keep you toasty. Finally, you’d asked if I’d like to come along. Well, you know, it’s hard to pass up on paradise, especially when a friend is headed up there! I’d love to! Let me see if I can get out of work around the time you plan to hit the road. It would be stellar to finally get to do this together! You’ll be hearing from me real soon! Thanks a ton for the invite; hoping to do this together! Your pal, Mohit TASK ANALYSIS The letter features many requisites of a good causal letter: The letter is addressed Dear + first name:Dear Carrie,The letter begins with a friendly opening phrase:Hope you’re doing splendidly!Contractions are used:you’re, I’d, you’ve, you’d, couldn’t, you’llPhrasal verbs are usedmull over- to thinkgo through- read, evaluateginger up- make excitingtake in- inhaleget out - bring outhead to - travel toClue someone in- give someone informationLook out for something- be watchful or careful about something.Come along- accompanyPass up on something- refuse somethingGet out of - escape, avoidInformal expressions and phrases are used:what with: because of (what with the camping holiday = because of the camping holiday)oh: expressing excitementchuffed: delightedbit: partYou’re going to love it!Get the city out of your lungs: escape the impure city air.Out in the open: outdoors, in the exteriorstreating your taste buds- relishing delicious foodas your eyes feast upon the raw beauty that surrounds…: enjoying the scenic viewit’s the best!Capital choice- excellent option.I guess- I believemagical vibe- uplifting atmosphere.Finally got to you- finally affected youDicey- risky, uncertainChilly - coldSundown- sunsetToasty- warm, cozyI’d love toStellar- exceptional, perfectReal soon- very soon.Idiomatic language is used:good pair of hands commanding the wheel - reliable driver managing the steering.Stay on top of things- be in controlHit the road - travel, set out on a journeyExclamation marks are used: !The letter ends with a friendly closing phrase:Thanks a ton for the invite; hoping to do this together!There is a casual sign-off, plus the letter writer’s first name:Your pal, MohitTask and analysis authored by Mohit Sehgal. For more on the IELTS, come over to http://Quora.com/q/nailtheielts

This is a good question, and it’s actually quite easy to get a high band in Task 1 General Training. The most important thing is to show that you have understood that the scenario calls for a friendly letter. This should be reflected in the choices you make with respect to vocabulary and sentence structure. Avoid overly formal expressions and write in a way that would make sense in the context of communication between friends. For example: “I am writing to inform you of my scheduled visit to your town” is completely inappropriate. Instead, write: “I’m writing to let you know I’ll be in your town next week”. Also, if you have an opportunity to show that you have developed rapport with this person, take it: “I know you like Chinese food, so I thought we could go to that restaurant by the promenade”. Perhaps most importantly, don’t overdo it. A lot of the advice on social media and the blogosphere is dangerously wrong about this. If you attempt to pepper your response with as many idioms and expressions as you can, your writing will come across as extremely artificial and even memorised. Keep it natural, simple, and to the point. Remember, IELTS is a test of your ability to communicate, not your ability to memorise idioms. If you’re a competent writer, idiomatic language will emerge naturally.
